name: Bronchus
description: Bronchi are conducting airways with walls containing cartilage plates, smooth muscle, and mucous glands. They are lined by pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium (respiratory epithelium).

features: Pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium with goblet cells
Irregular cartilage plates (vs C-shaped rings in trachea)
Spiral smooth muscle bands (muscle of Reissessen)
Fibroelastic connective tissue in lamina propria
location: Primary bronchi enter at hila of lungs
Branch into lobar and segmental bronchi
theory.examTips: Bronchi have cartilage and glands; bronchioles have neither. As airways branch: epithelium becomes simpler, cartilage disappears, smooth muscle increases proportionally. Asthma involves bronchial smooth muscle spasm and mucus hypersecretion.

name: Lung
description: Lung parenchyma consists of respiratory bronchioles, alveolar ducts, alveolar sacs, and alveoli. The alveoli are thin-walled air spaces for gas exchange, lined by Type I and II pneumocytes.

features: Alveoli: thin-walled air spaces for gas exchange
Type I pneumocytes: flat cells covering 95% of alveolar surface
Type II pneumocytes: cuboidal cells producing surfactant
Alveolar macrophages (dust cells) in alveolar spaces
Interalveolar septa with capillary network and elastic fibers
location: Right lung: 3 lobes; Left lung: 2 lobes
Base on diaphragm, apex extends above 1st rib
function: Gas exchange: O2/CO2 across blood-air barrier
Surfactant reduces surface tension, prevents atelectasis
theory.examTips: Blood-air barrier = Type I pneumocyte + fused basement membranes + capillary endothelium (~0.5 Î¼m thick). Type II pneumocytes produce surfactant and are progenitor cells. Surfactant appears at 24-28 weeks - premature babies risk RDS.

name: Trachea
description: The trachea is a fibromuscular tube reinforced by 16-20 C-shaped hyaline cartilage rings. It is lined by pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium with goblet cells (respiratory epithelium).

features: Pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium with goblet cells
Trachealis muscle spans posterior gap between cartilage ends
function: Conducts air from larynx to bronchi
Warms, humidifies, and filters inspired air
theory.examTips: Trachealis muscle allows esophageal expansion during swallowing. Cilia beat toward pharynx (mucociliary escalator). Goblet cells + ciliated cells = respiratory epithelium. Kartagener syndrome: immotile cilia causing recurrent infections, situs inversus.
